# List of nearest stars and brown dwarfs

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

![File:Flying among the closest stars to the Solar
System.ogv](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Flying_among_the_closest_stars_to_the_Solar_System.ogv/220px
--Flying_among_the_closest_stars_to_the_Solar_System.ogv.jpg)[Play
media](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/27/Flying_among_the_closest_stars_to_the_Solar_System.ogv
"Play media")

[](/wiki/File:Flying_among_the_closest_stars_to_the_Solar_System.ogv
"Enlarge")

Video showing the space around the nearest stars to the Sun.

This list contains all known stars and [brown dwarfs](/wiki/Brown_dwarf "Brown
dwarf") at a distance of up to 5 [parsecs](/wiki/Parsec "Parsec") (16.3
[light-years](/wiki/Light-year "Light-year")) from the [Solar
System](/wiki/Solar_System "Solar System"). In addition to the Solar System,
there are another 56 [stellar systems](/wiki/Stellar_systems "Stellar
systems") currently known lying within this distance. These systems contain a
total of 60 hydrogen-fusing [stars](/wiki/Star "Star") (of which 50 are [red
dwarfs](/wiki/Red_dwarf "Red dwarf")), 13 [brown dwarfs](/wiki/Brown_dwarf
"Brown dwarf"), and 4 [white dwarfs](/wiki/White_dwarf "White dwarf"). Despite
the relative proximity of these objects to Earth, only nine of them have an
[apparent magnitude](/wiki/Apparent_magnitude "Apparent magnitude") less than
6.5, which means only about 12% of these objects can be observed with the
[naked eye](/wiki/Naked_eye "Naked eye").[1] Besides the Sun, only three are
[first-magnitude stars](/wiki/List_of_brightest_stars "List of brightest
stars"): [Alpha Centauri](/wiki/Alpha_Centauri "Alpha Centauri"),
[Sirius](/wiki/Sirius "Sirius"), and [Procyon](/wiki/Procyon "Procyon"). All
of these objects are located in the [Local Bubble](/wiki/Local_Bubble "Local
Bubble"), a region within the [Orion–Cygnus
Arm](/wiki/Orion%E2%80%93Cygnus_Arm "Orion–Cygnus Arm") of the [Milky
Way](/wiki/Milky_Way "Milky Way").

##
List[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_nearest_stars_and_brown_dwarfs&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: List")]

Stars visible to the unaided eye have their magnitude shown in light blue
below. Brown dwarfs are shown with their designations in brown. White dwarfs
are shown with their designation in beige. The
[classes](/wiki/Spectral_classification "Spectral classification") of the
stars and brown dwarfs are shown in the color of their spectral types (these
colors are derived from conventional names for the spectral types and do not
represent the star's observed color). Many brown dwarfs are not listed by
[visual magnitude](/wiki/Visible_spectrum "Visible spectrum") but are listed
by near-IR [J band](/wiki/J_band_\(infrared\) "J band \(infrared\)")
[magnitude](/wiki/Magnitude_\(astronomy\) "Magnitude \(astronomy\)"). Some of
the [parallax](/wiki/Parallax "Parallax") and distance results are preliminary
measurements.[2]

## Future and
past[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_nearest_stars_and_brown_dwarfs&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Future and past")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Near-stars-past-
future-en.svg/350px-Near-stars-past-future-en.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Near-stars-
past-future-en.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Near-stars-past-future-en.svg "Enlarge")

Distances of the nearest stars from 20,000 years ago until 80,000 years in the
future

Backwards extrapolation of the motion of [Gamma
Microscopii](/wiki/Gamma_Microscopii "Gamma Microscopii") has shown that
approximately 3.8 million years ago, it was only around 6 light-years from the
Sun. Because it is a yellow giant, it would then have had an apparent
magnitude of −3, brighter than [Sirius](/wiki/Sirius "Sirius") currently is.

It is estimated that [Scholz's star](/wiki/Scholz%27s_star "Scholz's star")
and its companion brown dwarf passed about 52,000 astronomical units (0.25
parsecs; 0.82 light-years) from the Sun about 70,000 years ago.[40]

[Ross 248](/wiki/Ross_248 "Ross 248"), currently at a distance of 10.3 light-
years, has a [radial velocity](/wiki/Radial_velocity "Radial velocity") of −81
km/s. In about 31,000 years it may be the closest star to the Sun for several
millennia, with a minimum distance of 0.927 parsecs (3.02 light-years) in
36,000 years.[41] [Gliese 445](/wiki/Gliese_445 "Gliese 445"), currently at a
distance of 17.6 light-years, has a radial velocity of −119 km/s. In about
40,000 years it will be the closest star for a period of several thousand
years. [Gliese 710](/wiki/Gliese_710 "Gliese 710") is currently about 63.8
[light-years](/wiki/Light-year "Light-year") (19.6 [parsecs](/wiki/Parsec
"Parsec")) from [Earth](/wiki/Earth "Earth"), but its [proper
motion](/wiki/Proper_motion "Proper motion"), distance, and [radial
velocity](/wiki/Radial_velocity "Radial velocity")[42] indicate that it will
approach within a very small distance—perhaps under one light year—from the
[Sun](/wiki/Sun "Sun") within 1.4 million years, based on past and current
_[Hipparcos](/wiki/Hipparcos "Hipparcos")_ data.[43] At closest approach it
will be a first-magnitude star about as bright as [Antares](/wiki/Antares
"Antares"). The proper motion of Gliese 710 is very small for its distance,
meaning it is traveling nearly directly in our line of sight.

In a time interval of ±10 million years from the present, Gliese 710 is the
star whose combination of mass and close approach distance will cause the
greatest [gravitational](/wiki/Gravitation "Gravitation") perturbation of the
[Solar System](/wiki/Solar_System "Solar System").

[HIP 85605](/wiki/HIP_85605 "HIP 85605")'s spectral type and trajectory are
not fully understood. More-accurate astrometry is required to determine the
distance to the star, and thus if it will pass close to the Sun. It was
estimated in 2014 that HIP 85605 could approach to about 0.13 to 0.65 light-
years (0.04 to 0.2 pc) from the Sun within 240,000 to 470,000 years.

Known [Hipparcos](/wiki/Hipparcos "Hipparcos") stars that have passed or will
pass within 5.1 light-years of the Sun within ±2 million years:[43]
